params.text:
Professional Writing

Proofread your emails

Language in Action

• Use correct word order
  • Choose the correct tense
  • Match the verbs to the subject
Professional Writing : Introduction

This module will equip you with the skills to proofread your emails for common errors before sending them. 

You'll learn how to:

1. Use Correct Word Order: Ensure the subject, verb, and object are in the correct order for clear and grammatically correct sentences.

  2. Choose the Correct Tense: Select the verb tense that accurately reflects the timing of the action or event you are describing.

  3. Match the Verbs to the Subject: Make sure the verb agrees in number (singular or plural) with the subject of the sentence.
Use Correct Word Order -  Option 2
Subject-Verb-Object Order: This is the most common sentence structure in English.
Adjectives Before Nouns: Adjectives describe nouns and typically come before them in a sentence.
Wh- Questions: Questions that begin with "wh-" words follow a different order.

• Subject: The person or thing doing the action. (Example: I, You, They, The company)
  • Verb: The action being performed. (Example: write, order, receive)
  • Object: The receiver of the action (if there is one). (Example: an email, a package)

Example (Correct): We (subject) send (verb) emails (object) every day.

• Adjective: A word that describes a noun (Example: new, big, interesting)
  • Noun: A person, place, thing, or idea. (Example: printer, meeting, information)

Example (Correct): I ordered a new (adjective) printer (noun) yesterday.

• Wh- words: who, what, when, where, why, how

Example (Correct): What (wh- word) did you order (verb + subject)?
TIPS:

•    Read your email out loud. Does the word order sound natural?
•    If you're unsure, try rearranging the sentence to see if it makes more sense.
Use Correct Word Order -  Quiz

choices.question: Question 1 of 4: I need a _____ computer for the office.
Question 4 of 4: We _____ emails to our clients every week.

Use Correct Word Order - Read & Quiz
Read the opinions about using correct word order in emails, then choose the best answer for each question.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Alison says she uses a trick to write clear sentences in emails. What is the trick?
answers:
Following the Subject-Verb-Object order. 

Using lots of adjectives. 

Writing in capital letters.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Tarik says using the correct word order is important for accuracy in financial reports. Why is this?
answers:
It ensures the information is clear and easy to understand

It makes the reports look more professional. 

It allows him to use more technical vocabulary.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Natasha says keeping sentences simple helps with understanding. How does word order help with this?
answers:
Putting the subject, verb, and object in the correct order makes the meaning clear. 

It doesn't matter that much for short instructions. 

Using long and complex sentences is more impressive.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text: Alison:
Tarik:
Natasha:

Alison: I use the "Subject-Verb-Object" trick for my emails. It helps me write clear sentences, like "We received your order yesterday." If I'm not sure, I read the sentence out loud to see if it sounds natural.

Tarik: In financial reports, using the correct word order is important for accuracy. For example, "The sales figures increased last quarter" is much clearer than "Increased last quarter, the sales figures."
Natasha: When designing presentations, I sometimes need to write short email instructions. Keeping my sentences simple with the subject, verb, and object in order helps people understand them easily.
Choose The Correct Tense: Flashcards

dialogs.answer:
Used for habits, facts, and general truths.
Example: We send (present tense) emails every day.

Used for actions completed in the past.
Example: I ordered (past tense) a new printer yesterday.

Used to talk about future events.
Example: The package will arrive (future tense) tomorrow.

Used for actions completed at an unspecified time in the past or that began in the past and continue to the present.
 Example: I have received (present perfect) two emails from you today.

Used to describe an ongoing action or event happening at a specific time in the past.
Example: I was working (past continuous) on my presentation when you called.

Used to describe an ongoing action or event happening at a specific time in the present or around the present time.
Example: I am writing (present continuous) this email right now.

params.textField:
We *use* email to communicate with our clients.
I *placed* an order for a new computer last week.
The meeting *will start* at 10 am tomorrow.
I *have not received*  a confirmation email yet.
I *am currently working* on a new project proposal.
We *were discussing* the marketing campaign when the manager arrived.

params.text: Choose The Correct Tense: Quiz

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: We use email to communicate with our clients. (This describes a general habit, so we use the...)
Question 2 of 6: I placed an order for a new computer last week. (This describes an action completed in the past, so we use the...)
Question 3 of 6: The meeting starts at 10 am tomorrow. (This describes a future event, so we use the...)
Question 4 of 6: I have not received a confirmation email yet. (This describes an action completed in the past that affects the present, so we use the...)
Question 5 of 6: I am currently working on a new project proposal. (This describes an action happening now, so we use the...)
Question 6 of 6: We were discussing the marketing campaign when the manager arrived. (This describes an ongoing action in the past interrupted by another event, so we use the...)

Match The Verbs To The Subject: Flashcards

dialogs.answer:
Subjects: I, you, we, they (singular customer), he, she, it (singular customer)
Verbs: place, order, receive, confirm, send (referring to an order or confirmation)

Subjects: We, they (referring to a group of people)
Verbs: meet, discuss, decide, schedule, start (referring to a meeting)

Subjects: I, you, he, she, it (the person giving the presentation)
Verbs: give, present, discuss, explain, show (referring to a presentation)

Subjects: The conference, it (referring to the conference)
Verbs: take place, happen, be held, include, attract (referring to a conference

Subjects: HR department, they (referring to the HR department)
Verbs: hire, interview, train, offer, handle (referring to HR tasks)

params.text:

Read the flashcards to see useful words:

params.textField:
The HR department *is hiring* for a new marketing position.
The conference *takes place* in New York City every year
We *are meeting* with the marketing team tomorrow.
She *is giving* a presentation on sales figures this afternoon.
I *placed* an order yesterday.

params.textField: Tarik: In financial *reports*, clear verbs are important. We use verbs like "increased," "decreased," and "remained *stable*" to talk about how *numbers* change. This helps everyone understand the financial *situation* quickly.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.textField: Alison: In HR emails, I use verbs that *show* what the department is doing. For example, "We are *hiring*" or "We will be *interviewing*" clearly communicate the next steps in the recruitment process. It keeps *candidates* informed and avoids any confusion.

params.textField: Jemima: When I write emails about *architectural* plans, I use action verbs to describe the changes we make. For example, "add," "*remove*," or "*modify*" help explain the revisions clearly. It ensures everyone involved is on the same *page*.

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Choose the BEST answer for each question to demonstrate your understanding of the key skills for concluding professional writing effectively.

choices.question: Question 1 of 4: The most common sentence structure in English follows what order?
Question 2 of 4: Which tense is used for habits and general truths?
Question 3 of 4: The sentence "We received your order yesterday" uses which verb tense?
Question 4 of 4: In the sentence "The company is hiring for a new position," what is the subject?
